Okay, then maybe it's an okay idea if you really trust your devs.  I just don't have any experience with proftpd, sorry :-(
Security through obscurity?
If you're going to be the only one using it, why not just use WinSCP or something like it?
That's what I use for the kinds of situations you're describing.  It doesn't need a separate server either ... it works right through sshd using ssh as a secure tunnel.
You've used scp before, right?
I haven't bothered with ftp in many years now because it's yet another service that opens holes and isn't necessary.
scp is a command-line tool to securely copy files between remote locations and local locations.
It uses SSH as a tunnel.
Various GUIs for scp exist, like WinSCP, that provide an FTP-alike interface.
It's very good, you'll like it.

scp is good and simple when using it with people you trust because it just uses normal ssh accounts, e.g. your system accounts.  It doesn't replace a real ftp server because it doesn't have its own accounts ... so to make another account for someone to access scp with you have to make another system account.  You can set its shell to scp-only or whatever, but for a large number of different users, scp doesn't really make sense.
But if it's just for you, scp makes perfect sense.
Is the user you're logged in as in the www-data group, and are the perms on your www directory set to g+w ?
It's chown -R www-data:www-data <insert web directory here>
www-data:www-data gives the user and group name respectively, but if you don't give it stuff to work on, it won't have anything to do.
That should work.
-R is for recursive
